posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: On the WPILib website, i only see a class for single joint arm, is there any way I could modify it to simulate a double jointed arm?
The forces involved aren’t simple to calculate like they are for a single arm, see this whitepaper and related external simulator: Double Jointed Arm Physics + Control Simulator

link_counts.title: Double Jointed Arm Physics + Control Simulator

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
I haven’t had time to do this in the simulator yet, (we don’t have enough experienced programmers to get the rest of the stuff done without help).

From my reading of the docs, I think that I should be able to simulate a two joint arm in the simulator by treating each piece separately, and then appending them to another.   So, a two joint arm simulator looks like two single-joint arm simulators attached to each other.

This is no way going to model against real physics, but it should be able to help you make sure that your code is logically correct.

Checkout the docs for Mechanism2d and MechanismLigament2d .

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
We have been doing a bit of work in this area.  You may find this post from our programming team helpful.

3467 is doing similar work as well, see for example this post and others in their build thread.

posts.name: Emile Hamwey
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the mention @bbonner ! It is worth noting that our simulation has some pretty big caveats and so I wouldn’t recommend using it unless you need a very basic starting point or just want to play around with something that has a lower barrier to entry.

It is at best categorized as a visualizer rather than simulator, fairly specific to our use case (non-passthrough arm with only a few moves that require direct motion planning to avoid invalid states) and does very little in the way of gravity, dynamics simulation, feedforward implementation, or motion planning like 449’s and 6328’s do.
